chapter.title: The Scala Plugin
chapter.para: The Scala plugin extends the Java plugin to add support for Scala projects. It can deal with Scala-only projects and with mixed Java/Scala projects. It can even deal with Java-only projects. The Scala plugin supports joint compilation of Java and Scala source. This means your project can contain Scala classes which use Java classes, and vice versa.

section.title: Fast Scala Compiler
section.para:
The Scala plugin includes support for fsc, the Fast Scala Compiler. fsc runs in a separate daemon process and can speed up compilation significantly.
Note that fsc expects to be restarted whenever the contents of its compile class path change. (It does detect changes to the compile class path itself.) This makes it less suitable for multi-project builds.

section.title: Incremental compilation
section.para: Scala compilation can be sped up significantly by using an incremental compiler. After an initial full compilation, an incremental compiler will only recompile classes that are directly or indirectly affected by source code changes that have occurred since the previous compilation. This strategy is particularly effective when the source code changes between subsequent compilations are small and don't affect many other classes. Because incremental compilation requires sophisticated analysis of class dependencies, it can be slower than a full non-incremental build for larger source code changes or changes affecting many classes.

To support incremental compilation, Gradle integrates with Zinc, a standalone version of sbt's incremental Scala compiler. The Zinc compiler is selected with scalaCompileOptions.useAnt = false. Although not strictly necessary, it is recommended to execute the Zinc compiler in the Gradle compiler daemon (scalaCompileOptions.fork = true). Except where noted otherwise in the API documentation, the same configuration options are supported for the Zinc compiler as for the Ant based compiler (which is used by default). Also, joint compilation of Scala and Java code is still possible, with the Java code being compiled incrementally as well.

Incremental compilation requires analysis of the dependencies between classes. Each ScalaCompile task stores the results of this analysis in the file designated by scalaCompileOptions.incrementalOptions.analysisFile. The scalaCompileOptions.incrementalOptions.publishedCode property designates the classes directory or Jar file by which the compiled classes are passed on to the compile class path of any downstream ScalaCompile tasks. Downstream tasks will use this information to find all analysis files of code produced by upstream ScalaCompile tasks. The ScalaCompile tasks added by the Scala plugin have suitable defaults for both properties.

Note: As of Gradle 1.3, Zinc's Nailgun based daemon mode is not supported. Instead, we plan to enhance Gradle's own compiler daemon (activated with scalaCompileOptions.fork = true) to stay alive for longer than a single Gradle invocation. This will allow Gradle to keep the Scala compiler code warm, which has shown to result in another significant speedup for Scala compilation.
